caption: Davor Dragicevic last appeared in public at a rally in Banja Luka, Bosnia, on Dec. 30. He said in a Facebook video this week that he had gone into hiding.

candidates.title: In Bosnia, a Fathers Grief Swells Into an Antigovernment Movement
candidates.content:
BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina  After his 21-year-old son David was found dead in a creek last March, Davor Dragicevic, a waiter in a cafe, took matters into his own hands.
Dissatisfied with official explanations that David Dragicevic had been a drug addict and a thief, and had killed himself or been murdered by a criminal gang, Mr. Dragicevic started a one-man protest movement that has grown into the largest antigovernment demonstration in Bosnia in decades.
Now the elder Mr. Dragicevic, 49, has not been seen in public since Dec. 30, when he led thousands on a march around Banja Luka, the capital of the Serb autonomous region in eastern Bosnia, demanding the resignation of the interior minister, Dragan Lukac. He was last seen by local journalists as he was being pursued by plainclothes police officers.
The Bosnian Serb police have issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Dragicevic, charging him with incitement and threatening public safety. On Monday, Mr. Dragicevic posted a video message on Facebook.
candidates.description: The case of David Dragicevic, who was found dead in March, has become a rallying point for people disaffected with the Bosnian Serb politician Milorad Dodik.

result.explanation: The news caption stating that "Davor Dragicevic last appeared in public at a rally in Banja Luka, Bosnia, on Dec. 30. He said in a Facebook video this week that he had gone into hiding" is supported by the information found in the related article. The article from The New York Times provides essential details affirming that Davor Dragicevic led a protest in Banja Luka on December 30 and has not been seen in public since that date. Additionally, it confirms that he is currently in hiding due to a warrant for his arrest issued by Bosnian Serb police, resulting from charges of incitement and threatening public safety. Furthermore, it mentions that he indeed posted a video message on Facebook, which verifies the second part of the caption about going into hiding. There are no contradictions noted in the article regarding the last public appearance or the claims he made about his current situation. Therefore, the caption's claims align consistently with the information provided in the article, demonstrating a reliable correspondence between the news caption and reliable reporting on the situation.
